title: Russell's Attic 1-2, by SL Huang (Zero Sum Game, Half Life)

Description:

Cas Russell is good at math. Scary good.

The vector calculus blazing through her head lets her smash through armed men twice her size and dodge every bullet in a gunfight. She can take any job for the right price and shoot anyone who gets in her way.

As far as she knows, sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the only person around with a superpower . . . but then Cas discovers someone with a power even more dangerous than her own. Someone who can reach directly into peopleÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s minds and twist their brains into Moebius strips. Someone intent on becoming the worldÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s puppet master.

Someone whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s already warped CasÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s thoughts once before, with her none the wiser.

Cas should run. Going up against a psychic with a god complex isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t exactly a rational move, and saving the world from a power-hungry telepath isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t her responsibility. But she isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t about to let anyone get away with violating her brain -- and besides, sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s got a small arsenal and some deadly mathematics on her side. ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s only one problem . . .

She doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know which of her thoughts are her own anymore.

Description:

Cas Russell is back Ã¢â‚¬â€ and so is her deadly supermath. 

Cas may be an antisocial mercenary who uses her instant calculating skills to mow down enemies, but sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s trying hard to build up a handful of morals. So when sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s hired by an anguished father to rescue his kid from an evil tech conglomerate, it seems like the perfect job to use for ethics practice. 

Then she finds her clientÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s daughter . . . who is a robot. 

The researchers who own the Ã¢â‚¬â„¢bot will stop at nothing to get it back, but the kidÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just real enough for Cas to want to protect her Ã¢â‚¬â€ even though she knows sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s risking everything for a collection of metal and wires. But when the case blows up in her face, it plunges Cas into the crossfire of a massive, decades-long corporate espionage war. 

Cas knows logically that she isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t saving a child. SheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s stealing a piece of technology, one expensive and high-stakes enough that spiriting it away is going to get innocent people killed. But she has a distraught father on one hand and a robot programmed to act like a distraught daughter on the other, and sheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s never been able to sit by when a kid is in trouble Ã¢â‚¬â€ even a fake one. 

Screw morals and ethics. All Cas wants to do is save one little girl.
